content:
Bors could just take the version from src/version. Labels could be of the form V-1.58.0 or V-landed-in-1.58.0. The same could be done for issues: V-fixed-in-1.58.0. Of course this could also be done by another bot.
Thoughts?
@Hans Kratz PRs already get milestones assigned when they're merged
That wouldn't work for issues though since you couldn't tell "fixed in 1.58" apart from "regressed in 1.58", hmm
Why does it feel like you always post faster than me? /lh
Because I'm obsessively online lol

I feel like for issues it's easy enough to look at the fix PR, which is usually linked on the side. I'm not strongly advocating against adding labels, it's just that they would get to be a lot super quickly.
Yeah, currently t-release uses milestones for the regression date which seems more useful

I feel like for issues it's easy enough to look at the fix PR, which is usually linked on the side. I'm not strongly advocating against adding labels, it's just that they would get to be a lot super quickly.

I say this as someone who regularly scrolls through all of the labels to find the ones that make sense for a given issue.
I just missed that the milestone is already set on merged PRs. :sweat_smile: So yeah, just for issues it probably does not make sense if you can get it with a click on the linked PR.

One thing that I'll toss out, as a strawman, is "fixed-in-nightly", "fixed-in-beta", "fixed-in-stable" (or should it be "on"?). That way you would know when the fix for something is expected to land at a glance. I'd guess it's probably not worth it though.
And it would become outdated, once the train moves on. We already have this problem with regression-from-stable-to-nightly when nightly becomes the new beta.
Well, you'd want to automate it.
In fact, we really should automate it for the regression labels.
I may look into that sometime.
But yeah, that's a fair point. It wouldn't work at all unless it was automatically kept up to date.
Bors could just post a comment instead of using labels, right?
Yes but that seems awfully easy to lose in noisy issues
It could edit the issue description but not sure how helpful it would be
Most issues and PRs aren't much commented on after merge/close. In probably 98% of cases just a comment from bors would sit as close enough to the last comment to stay visible.
Issues can have milestone too. When a PR is merged and links to an issue that it fixes, we could automatically apply that milestone to the issue as well.

Joshua Nelson said:

currently t-release uses milestones for the regression date which seems more useful

currently t-release uses milestones for the regression date which seems more useful

On the other hand:

  • That is not how the milestone field is generally used on Github thus causing confusion for new contributors.
  • The milestone field having a different, non-obvious meaning only for issues that are regressions is confusing.
  • Many issues are not regressions or the version in which the regression was introduced is unknown.

the milestone is used for "this issue should be looked at by this release's ship date" which seems to match how ~everyone uses it, or so I would guess? We sometimes retag particular issues even if we miss a particular release, for example
